quotes.t: But the Democratic presidential nominee is commonly referred to as Elvis, and his running mate as Eddie Haskell, that {qword}obsequious{/qword} weenie from '50s TV.
He could wear an oxford shirt and necktie and speak the local language, in every sense, and never act {qword}obsequious{/qword} or look as though he felt out of place.
Nash's other hand flashed forward a lighter with the {qword}obsequious{/qword} speed of a motor salesman.
The {qword}obsequious{/qword} villagers touched their caps but sneered behind her back.

subsource.source: in V. S. Pritchett: {it}A Man of Letters{/it}

et: Middle English, compliant, from Latin {it}obsequiosus{/it}, from {it}obsequium{/it} compliance, from {it}obsequi{/it} to comply, from {it}ob-{/it} toward + {it}sequi{/it} to follow {ma}{mat|ob-|}, {mat|sue|}{/ma}
shortdef: marked by or exhibiting a fawning attentiveness
